title: CryptSafe
author: CryptSafe
created_time: December 01, 2022, 10:24:38 PMLast edit: December 01, 2022, 10:58:35 PM by CryptSafe
content: In continuation of my course on the Bitcoin Promotion and Adoption in my locality, this is the phase two (2) while you can see the phase one (1) here; https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5422241.0  I on-boarded this young man who render laundry  services in my locality. He was recommended to be a good laundry man in my locality for which he has been up and doing. He owns a mini Laundry service which he has been running and has been his major source of income and sustenance. I met with him and we had a conversation. At first, he seems to be sound and knowledgeable enough to assimilate new ideas and mostly innovations. He is also inclined a bit in technological innovations and discoveries so I told him about bitcoin. I used the scheme I already used for the previous as earlier stated which he find interesting. It was a series of question and answer session we had an in-depth discussion on blockchain, cryptocurrency and bitcoin. After which, he told me he is interested in accepting bitcoin as payment for his services and I should show him how he could start  by setting up a wallet which I did.  For  better view, here was the scheme which I used;1. What is Bitcoin?2. When and why Bitcoin was founded.3. Founder of Bitcoin.4. Importance and benefits of holding bitcoin.5. How to trade bitcoin. ( listed some  notable exchange where he can trade bitcoin)6. What is blockchain and how it works.As I did for the previous,  I also did to him as well. I taught him how to set up a bitcoin wallet, the easiest to be precise so he could easily understand and do it himself, copy and send his wallet address to his customers for payment. As earlier mentioned above, I also told and showed him the difference between private keys, public keys  and transaction harsh so he could get acquainted to them all.I encouraged him to reach out to his friends and colleagues  because it would aid in the faster and rapid adoption and promotion of bitcoin in other locality where they belong.This course for which I have started has been an interesting one so far. It has exposed me to lots of experience as well and also knowing more  of the societal perspective about Bitcoin  and cryptocurrency as a whole. It has been a wonderful one and time out there for me as I made new friends in my locality and beyond.If I can take this course to my locality and beyond, you too can do it more. I am open to welcoming contributions and opinions.

comments.author: coupable
comments.body: One of the things that excites me the most is seeing people using Bitcoin for their small businesses. But it occurs to me that it is easy to do this in services that are managed on the Internet without the need to obtain licenses, while this will be a problem if that business is run in a country that does not fully recognize the acceptance of bitcoin payments. In addition to the technical problems in accepting crypto payments, on the basis of which the prices of goods and services are supposed to be determined.

comments.author: notocactus
comments.body: To use Bitcoin as a payment method like what you and your locals are doing, it makes sense to remind you and your friends remember to use non custodial wallets such as Electrum wallet to use.Because you will easily to make transaction with very cheap transaction fee less than $0.1 per transaction (assume you use high fee rate). It is good about transaction fee but also makes sense because you will not have to rely on centralized exchanges. They usually charge you very expensive withdrawal fee (if you don't use feature to send internal like Binance) and centralized exchanges can scam anytime.References for exchange withdrawal feeGuide to check fees: Taker, maker, deposit, withdrawal, transaction feesOld story. Exchanges get profits from users' withdrawal fees.

comments.author: Welsh
comments.body: Quote from: CryptSafe on December 01, 2022, 10:24:38 PMAs I did for the previous,  I also did to him as well. I taught him how to set up a bitcoin wallet, the easiest to be precise so he could easily understand and do it himself, copy and send his wallet address to his customers for payment. As earlier mentioned above, I also told and showed him the difference between private keys, public keys  and transaction harsh so he could get acquainted to them all.Out of curiosity, what wallet did you teach him to setup? Was it by their choice or did you sort of recommend a wallet? The reason I ask is; since in your phase one you've already taught them the basics, and the benefits of Bitcoin. Did you allow them to make a educated choice on what wallet to select? Also, be interested whether they selected a hot wallet or a completely offline wallet? I'm definitely not criticising you there, with those questions. I'm just wondering, since I believe there's teaching, and there's teaching things correctly. You should be allowing them to use the information that you've fed them, without actually being too biased, and then allow them to use their own initiative. That way, you can sort of check whether they've truly understood what you've just been teaching them too. It's one of the reasons I avoid teaching people about Bitcoin. I don't consider myself to the proficiency required to teach them about Bitcoin. I usually just point them to references, because I don't want to teach them wrong, which could potentially be dangerous.

comments.author: Welsh
comments.body: Quote from: m2017 on December 02, 2022, 03:08:24 PMPeople are lazy creatures and until the need arises, they will not use bitcoin as a means of payment. Why, if there are simple and familiar traditional ways. You can get out of your comfort zone and learn new things if there is a strong need. Start accepting only btc for payment and you will see how quickly the world will change.Generally, users have to be annoyed at the current system to change, since it's quite well known that us humans don't particularly relish change in our lives. So, things like a bank interrupting your transaction or potentially being locked out of your account are things that force people to look at alternatives. That's not a bad thing, there will be plenty of users getting annoyed at the traditional money system, and this is only accelerated by the recessions that we keep dipping into. Every time inflation pops its ugly head up, there will be people questioning why it continues to happen, and will soon come to the realization they're getting poorer despite holding the same amount of money.

comments.author: DapanasFruit

comments.body: I am inspired to see a very good local-based initiative for the community to get into Bitcoin and do some business in the process. I look at Bitcoin as the new way of using money the digital money and if more and more people can be buying and selling with the use of Bitcoin we are actually building a new economy away from the necessary controls and schemes of the traditional institutions we have around. However, as a very simple non-techie person, the most important challenge when I was starting with Bitcoin years ago is always the learning curve which is so important especially in protecting the crypto we have in our wallets. There are surely many risks but we know that benefits can also be astounding not just for speculators (which all of are) but also for people who loves the idea of empowering themselves.
